You had no idea what to expect when you first pledged to rescue Bilbo, but the tribulations you've encountered thus far were quite unexpected. Even so, you've overcome each—including dispatching the horrific Ungoliant's spawn—and are closing the distance to the captive hobbit. You look around the party. Though no words are said, it is clear that you remain united in your resolve. Weariness falls away, and you continue down the trail with renewed purpose.
The air suddenly goes still—even the ever-present chattering of birds ceases abruptly. You stop, peering into the surrounding trees just as arrows fly at you from seemingly all directions.

You pause at last for much-needed nourishment after countless hours spent tramping through the forest. Employing clever woodcraft, you have gathered sustenance along the way. Though perhaps meager individually, the handfuls of berries, tubers, and small game form a veritable feast.<i>

You will have to backtrack your course in order to free yourselves.

Welcome to the Early Access Tutorial for The Lord of the Rings: Living Card Game. You are about to play a rough cut of the gameplay tutorial which sets the scene for the first campaign — The Shadow's Reach. We will be polishing this tutorial further during our Early Access period, revising the flow, changing narrative beats and dialog, and further improving the experience for the eventual Full Release.

While there is more to discover that will help you on your Quest, you have learned the fundamentals that will carry you through this battle. It is down to you, now—defeat the King Spider, destroy the nest, and win the day!

The first time you log in every 24 hours, the game generates a challenge tied to a random unlocked Quest. Completing each daily challenge grants you Valor (and potential additional rewards)
Achievements that are tracked over the lifetime of your account
A card type that refers to any Hero or Ally

Located on the upper left of every Ally, Attachment, Event, and Sauron card, this is the Resource amount needed to play that card. Hero units do not have a cost, since they begin the game already in play
A trait type representing one of the countless variety of beasts found throughout Middle-earth
A trait type representing a person from the city-state of Men in northeastern Rhovanion

A deck of 30 cards based on 3 Hero units of your choice. You build each deck based on the Heroes, and you cannot have more than 2 copies of any individual card. You select a deck each time you begin a Quest. During the Quest, you can rollover the deck to see how many remain
Upon being defeated, a unit is discarded from play. This can occur if the unit falls to 0 Health or through some other means

Selecting a Character's Defense button gives that unit the Guard keyword for the round. Attacking or exhausting the unit cancels Defense and removes Guard. At the start of the next round, the Character then readies as normal. Activating Defense again requires a new action that round
The challenge level you face in a Quest: Easy, Normal, or Hard. Sauron gains more Resources as the difficulty goes up, but you can gain greater rewards if you survive
A trait type representing one of the Dúnedain, the Men of the West
The action of applying a Character's progress to an Objective

Your Quest ends in failure, leaving Bilbo to a horrible fate.
An anguished Glóin arrives at Beorn's Hall with dreadful news: a great spider has captured Bilbo Baggins! He beseeches a hardy band of heroes to help rescue his dear friend.

The Lady and her brood are gathered at the edge of their lair. A band of Orcs and Goblins have emerged from the trees. Some heave empty wagons, others carry torches.

A huge Orc tromps to stand before the Lady.

"The moon is full, spidey. Ufthak comes to collect!" he snarls.

The Lady chitters at her lieutenants, who rush into the webs. The spiders soon return with web-wrapped cocoons, depositing them in front of the Orc captain. Goblins rush to gather the cocoons, loading them into carts. As the last cocoons are loaded, a hooded Goblin begins screeching at Ufthak, pointing to a parchment full of hash marks.

Ufthak glares at the yelling Goblin for a moment, then blinks and pivots back to the Lady.

"We one short, leggy." The Orc's grainy voice is mild, but laced with promise of violence. "Cold masters don't like… short. Ufthak don't like… short. We had deal!"

After recovering, Wilelk thanks you profusely. Over the past few months, he tells you, a number of tribesmen have gone mysteriously absent. He suspects they've fallen prey to similar circumstances, but offers no explanation as to why the great spiders have suddenly become so daring.

Afraid to return home through the forest alone, Wilelk offers to join you and suggests which direction the spiders were taking him.

Somewhere under the never-ending trees before you, an old hobbit awaits rescue… or doom.
Your Quest ends in failure, leaving Bilbo to a horrible fate.
Tracking Bilbo's abductors to their lair, you are surprised to see Spiders and Orcs together. Whatever their plans for Bilbo, you are determined to stop them.

The forest floor is awash with the marks of ironshod feet and wagon tracks. You begin slowly to make sense of the situation: The spiders are gathering slaves for a host of Orcs, intended for some devilry yet to be understood. Deep in thought, you hike a sensible distance from the spider’s lair to camp for the night, unsure of what to do next. As the shadows coalesce into night, you hear someone—something—creeping through the undergrowth beyond the firelight. After silent glances, a few nods, and a quick dash, the creep is quickly caught. Shrieking like a stuck pig, it bites and flails about with surprising strength. Its energy soon spent, the creature curls itself into a sobbing ball. You catch a few words amongst its rambling litany of self-pity, such as “precious” and… a name? Could it be? How that name would be known to the wretch, you cannot guess. For the creature is muttering “Baggins.”
Your Quest ends in failure, leaving Bilbo to a horrible fate.
You find a pitiful creature that claims it can help you find Bilbo… but are you sure you can trust the wretched thing?

Sméagol has betrayed you. Somehow the villain has triggered the chamber’s mechanism, causing one side of the floor to abruptly drop. Your legs slip violently as you flail down the steep angle, fingers desperately grasping for any hold. Amidst the cacophony of sliding rubble, supplies, and Orc bodies, you catch sight of Sméagol dangling from one of the chains above.

“Goodbyeses, masters!” he shrieks. “Baggins and Precious. For Sméagol they are! Miiine!”

His shrill voice fades as you slide past the lip of the slanted floor and drop into a rancid darkness. You blink twice before meeting the wet ground with a mucky plop, debris raining down around you.

Then a falling barrel lands directly on your head and everything goes black.
Your Quest ends in failure, leaving Bilbo to a horrible fate.
Your pursuit of Bilbo has brought you to a tower hidden deep in Mirkwood. You must be careful not to draw the attention of every foul creature that calls this dark place home.

You’re elated to have found Bilbo, but the situation is grim. Just beyond the broken door, Ufthak and his Orc warriors are preparing a second attack. You cannot hold them off forever.

Trapped and near despair, you prepare for a last stand. But wait… a shaft of moonlight attracts your eye.

Screams and pleas from the other cells tear at your conscience, but there’s no time. As you swear one day to return for the poor souls, Ufthak commences the second onslaught. Quickly, you lift a reluctant Bilbo out the high window, following headlong yourself.

You crash onto a steep slope and tumble violently down through branches and brambles, until deposited with a splash into a cold stream. You see Bilbo a small distance ahead, treading water and sighing, “Oh no, old boy. Not again!”

The current of the stream is strong, dragging you quickly downriver. In the distance, you hear the now-familiar cries of an Orc pursuit. You’re not in the clear yet.
Your Quest ends in failure, leaving Bilbo to a horrible fate.
Bilbo is free, but now you face the retribution of his former captors. Your only hope of salvation is to flee down the nearby Anduin and seek refuge with the elves of Lórien.

Bilbo rests his head against one of the great Mallorn trees and takes another breath of otherworldly air.

For several weeks now, the old Hobbit has convalesced in Lórien. What a place, and what rest it has been. Beautiful, eternal, majestic… and somehow lit by gentle sorrow and longing, this place is. Where Rivendell, like its master, stands uniquely between the immortal and the natural, Lórien is utterly immortal. A place impossible for mortals to truly understand, especially Hobbits.

While Bilbo’s journey to this place had been altogether unexpected and entirely circuitous, he was glad to have seen the Golden Wood. The place strangely soothed the secret darkness that sometimes pulled at his heart, as the abyss may pull at the one who stares into it.

Splendid as Lórien was, Bilbo felt healed and was ready to move on. He longed to see Dale and the Lonely Mountain, and the thought of Rivendell pricked a homesick pang in his soul.

The creature glanced furtively down at the land of golden hues. Even at night, the unhealthy glow of the place hurt its eyes; and even at a distance, the air of the place hurt its lungs.

The thief, the miserable trickster—Baggins—had gone into that terrible place and the creature had lost the trail. It wringed long fingers in misery, cursing the bright light of the white eye above. Sniffling and sobbing, it crawled down the stony slope, staying into the darkest shadows where possible.

The creature considered returning to the forest, but knew in its heart of hearts that its time there had passed. There was something in the south. Something the creature could not define. Something that tugged at it, like instinct or the smell of fish. A sense that tasted like metal, like a tinge of the Precious. South.

The creature turned to follow the rocky bank. It preferred to move in shadows carved by the moonlight, and it soon disappeared into the deeper shadows that lay to the south.
but it took some time to do
Your journey has come to a tragic end.
You have reached the land of the Beornings at last. But a new complication arises: Their leader, Grimbeorn the Old, is missing!

"Fine work," Grimbeorn says, looking upon the defeated Trolls. "I am in your debt." You explain that encountering him was not mere happenstance. The Beorning chieftain grows somber as you share the news of unrest along Mirkwood's borders, then gives a decisive nod. "Come; I would hear more of the King of Dale's offer. And there is that beer I promised!" You smile despite your weariness. Uniting the Beornings and Men of Dale against the forces marshaling within Mirkwood addresses but one threat of many. Yet, wherever your next adventure may lead, you take heart that the Free Peoples shall rise to the challenge…

Against all odds, you have escaped Mirkwood Forest. Before you stretches the vales of Anduin, and the Misty Mountains beyond. The next leg of your journey lies to the south: the realm of the Beornings. Having seen firsthand the menace rising within Mirkwood, you know well the urgency to your mission. Still, you grant yourself a brief pause to gather your strength, the clear sky being a welcome change from your time under Mirkwood's dark canopy…

An unearthly shriek reverberates through the predawn woods as Ungoliant's Spawn thrashes about in her death throes. Even as her swollen carcass twitches its last, you spare no time to revel in victory. Eager to leave this place behind, you strike out deeper into the forest to continue your mission…

The battle is hard fought, but at last you stand triumphant. Even so, it is but a momentary victory. Sparing a last look at the evidence of your defiance, you clamber back aboard the raft to complete your journey to the Beornings…

After defeating the Spider, you find the small creature cowering a short distance away, muttering about being betrayed. After you calm him down and explain that you are looking for a hobbit, he perks up and says that he knows where the foul goblins took him. He even offers to guide you to them... though you are not sure you should trust this creature.
You have found the tower where Bilbo is being kept.

The King of Dale seeks an alliance with the Beornings and you have agreed to act as his envoy. To reach their lands, you must brave the dangers of Mirkwood Forest.

Although weary from your trevails, you summon the strength to cross the enchanted river. Having its dark waters between you and your pursuers brings some measure of relief, but you know well that further dangers lie ahead. You continue your journey, even more determined to warn the Beornings of the unrest stirring within Mirkwood Forest…

While the party was focused on destroying the spiders' nest, a massive spider lunged from the shadows to capture Bilbo and steal him away! Glóin recognized that the beast was a spawn of Ungoliant, a spider of tremendous power. He reazlied must return to the nearby Beornings to organize a rescue party for Bilbo.

The mission clear, Glóin returned to the Hall of Beorn with the greatest of haste.

The tranquility of Beorn’s Hall was shattered when a devastated Glóin arrived, exhausted and anguished. The old Dwarf tearfully explained how he’d met Bilbo in the outskirts of the Greenwood, and how they’d been ambushed by great spiders who’d taken the dear Hobbit. “And to think that Bilbo Baggins rescued us from such webs; it’s almost more than I can bear,” sobbed the old Dwarf. “If only Gandalf were here.” Alas, the grey wizard was nowhere near Beorn’s Hall, but another group of hardy folks had arrived shortly after Bilbo left for his evening walk.

The time has come to begin your journey. 

Go forth, and fare well!
Defeat each Enemy in play to complete the Quest

Navigating through the dense forest toward the smoke is no easy task, but at last you find the remains of an old Woodsmen village. Even more welcome to your eyes is the clear blue sky in the distance: you stand near the eaves of Mirkwood! Your relief is short-lived, however, as the village is overrun with Orcs! They spot your weary group, making it clear that you must fight to reach the Anduin Vale.

After arriving at Beorn’s Hall, you've learned the famous Bilbo Baggins was taken by Mirkwood spiders mere hours ago. Without hesitation, you volunteer to find and retrieve the Hobbit—hopefully before he’s consumed… or worse.

And so you find yourself before Greenwood the Great, that the wary and wise call Mirkwood. A sleeping evil once inhabited the Greenwood, but was purged many years ago. The forest has since known a period of peace and the return of wholesome life.

As the shadows now gather under the trees, you sense a foulness on the air. You fear evil may have returned to this realm.

You begin to search for clues as to which direction the spiders took Bilbo.

There are ample signs of recent struggle in the small glade, and several of the Hobbit's possessions are strewn about. After a few moments, you notice a gleam of metal on the forest floor… perhaps a sign?

You're about to investigate, as several giant spiders creep into the glade. They don't seem at all interested in assisting the search. Quite the contrary.
Find a way across the stream

Bilbo's mind must have been clear during the first moments after his capture. You notice that he slid his sword along the undergrowth as he was hauled away. When the spider's poison immobilized him, he must have dropped Sting.

Encouraged, you venture into the shadowy green-gray wilderness that is Mirkwood.

A small cocoon is dropped before the Lady. “Eats it, m’lady! Scrumptious it is. Tasty. Sweet!” The skinny creature squeals in pleasure and anticipation, jumping to and fro on arms and legs as if a spider himself. The creature gives the cocoon a kick. “False it is, Baggins. Trickster, thief, cheater gollum, gollum. Eats it, eeeats it!” The enormous spider moves to hover over the cocoon. Spear-sized mandibles emerge slowly from its dripping maw. “Suck it to boneses. m'lady! No hangingness or dryingness needed. Not like tough dwarvses or tricky elvses. Sweet and juicy, Hobbit is. Just leave clothses, m'lady gollum, gollum. For Precious, Precious is in its pocketses. My Precious." The spider monstrosity is about to delve into her meal when a sudden noise is heard from the edge of the lair. Flapping its hands nervously and bobbing its scrawny neck, the creature pleads: "Don't listen to woodsy noises, m'lady. Eat—eeeat—while Hobbit is warmses." Someone has arrived, and the spiders move to greet them.

For hours you delve into the menacing forest. Thorny undergrowth and sticky crawlers grab at you as if with minds of their own.

A subtle change in the echo of the wood heralds a change in scenery, and you soon come upon a dark gurgling stream. While the watery smells and soothing sounds relax you, you've been warned not to trust any water in Mirkwood—save for that gathered from fresh rain.

The spiders must have crossed the stream by traversing the canopies above, but how will you cross? A nearby dead tree may be the answer.

You attempt to push at the dry trunk, hoping for it to fall and bridge the stream. Unfortunately, your efforts attract the local wildlife.

The dead tree falls across the stream with a splintery crack. You use the fallen trunk to step across, careful to not slip. What could cause wild creatures to attack so? Perhaps the corrupted stream is their main source of water?

As you jump off the trunk on the far side, a deep rumble greets you. For a brief moment, you wonder what could make such a sound… but only for a brief moment. For, out of the shadows, shambles an enormous black bear.

It roars.

The sound is staggering. It fills the air like a living thing, terrifying and primordial. The impact of the roar sends you reeling backwards, almost into the stream.

It charges. An avalanche of fur, teeth, and claws.

Before the monotony of the forest claws at you again, you come upon a sudden clearing. The sluggish breeze and wan gray light of the dell are a welcome change from the humid twilight of the forest.

On the far side of the clearing, you spy what you've been looking for: A group of large spiders, hovering over a tightly-wound cocoon.

It's time for a rescue!
You must defeat the monstrous spiders

Ufthak moves a hand to the pommel of his sheathed blade. Several spiders flinch back, but the huge female stands her ground, glowering down at the insolent Orc commander. For a long moment, there is complete silence. 

Finally, she chitters quietly at one of the nearby spiders. The minion moves quickly into the lair to drag Bilbo’s cocoon towards the gateway. 

As the spider drags the last cocoon before Ufthak, a small skinny creature flies out of the shadows, screeching “Preciousss!” like a dying animal. It wraps its arms around Ufthak’s thick neck and bites his right ear. Black gore spills, and Ufthak’s furious roar joins the creature's tinny wail. 

The screams echo through the trees and cobwebs.

As you make your way through the dense forest, a sudden shriek is heard from afar.

Praying that Hobbits are incapable of so pitiful a sound, you move quickly to investigate its source.

The forest soon shows signs of giant spiderwebs. At first, only a few thick strands are seen between canopy and trunk, but the webbing quickly grows denser. Before long, the sticky ropes are thick enough to block your path.

About to hack away at the webbing, you sense a subtle shift in the shadows and glance up.

Only a few feet above your head, the myriad glare of malicious eyes observe you.

Mandibles drip with ichor. Bloated bodies tremble with anticipation.
Open the cocoons to rescue your companions

It has gone from bad to worse. You ventured into Mirkwood to free a captured Hobbit, but now two of your party have themselves been captured.

Unwholesome strands break apart with a snap as you cut and saw your way deeper into the lair. Mercifully, the web’s denizens are either absent or preoccupied, for you catch only brief glances of hairy bodies moving through this world of pale webbing and gray-green murk.

After slow and tiring progress, you come upon the nexus of the lair: An eldritch clearing devoid of webs, except for the huge sinister shape of a dead tree. Cocoons of many sizes hang from the branches like depraved fruit.

A few of the cocoons are of approximate size to your lost friends. One even moves fitfully.

You move to open the cocoons, but the lair’s inhabitants have finally noticed the intrusion into their midst. Clacking spiders soon surround you—strangely in league with several Orcs!

Bruised and bloodied, the creature whimpered at the cruelness of the world. It would have been killed had the Orcs not been distracted by the intruders in the Lady’s pantry.

It had escaped into the tangled undergrowth and shrouded itself in shadows, from where it had seen Ufthak and his caravan depart. All that remained was the faint creaking of the wagons fading into the gloom.

The Lady remained before the gateway. When the clangor of battle from within the lair diminished, she began to shift her monstrous bulk.

A strange and battle-worn band soon emerged from the webs, faces paling in despair at the sight of the bloated monster.

The Lady of Bogwood, Broodmother of the Western Forest, descendant of great Ungoliant herself, lost her composure and hissed with rage. These strangers had defiled her sanctum, her lair.

Punishment was due.

<size=130%><align=center>
Follow the Orc caravan <size=80%>(gain by Day and Dark)</size>; or trust Sméagol <size=80%>(gain Sméagol)</size></align></size>
Persuade the creature to help you find Bilbo

After defeating a colony of Mirkwood spiders, you discover that the eight-legged abominations had been gathering slaves for a host of Orcs. You believe Bilbo Baggins was taken south alongside other prisoners.

Before deciding on your next course of action, you capture an unpleasant creature lurking about your camp. To your surprise, the creature appears to know the name “Baggins.”

The creature already looks beaten and bruised, so you attempt to use kindness to extract information. However, after being fed both food and gentle words, the nasty thing remains thoroughly unhelpful.

Before dawn, a more pressing problem arises. As dull gray seeps into the black edges of night, flying dark shapes begin to swoop under the branches above you. They rapidly multiply and before long, it's as if you’ve been caught inside a black whirlwind.

You have neither time nor inclination to follow the strange Sméagol creature. Rather, by day or dark, you’ll chase down the Orc caravan to free its captives, especially Bilbo. You gather your packs and set off.

Sméagol watches you go. His ghoulish eyes glow dull yellow. After a few moments, he slinks away into the trees, muttering to himself. You wonder whether you’ll see the wretch again. You hope not.

The caravan is easily tracked and you make good time. Even so, the day is mostly spent before you hear the faint noise of rolling wheels ahead. Exultant to have reached your quarry, you hasten your steps, hoping to surprise and overwhelm the caravan’s rearguard.

In the excitement, you forget to consider the keen noses and sharp ears of Goblins. As you round a copse of dead trees, you suddenly find yourself facing a group of enemies, alert and weapons ready.

So much for surprise.

Follow Sméagol as he finds a way through the marsh.
<color=red>Sméagol must survive</color>

You decide trusting Sméagol is worth the risk. If the creature knows a way to get ahead of the caravan, you’ll have a significant advantage in rescuing Bilbo from the Orcs. As you follow Sméagol through the thick vegetation, the terrain begins to dip. Before long, the air is laced with mist and the soil grows spongy. You’re being led into a swamp. “Swampses, yess. Cool nice swampses,” Sméagol explains. “With frogses, fishes, and snakeses, precious. Tasty, gollum, gollum.” He pauses to crane his neck and sniff the air. “Sméagol looks to find right spot, masters. Safe way through mist and bogses. Orcses and wagonses must go 'round, you see. No tasty frogses for Orcses, gollum.” Sméagol continues to sniff around the area looking for some landmark, some sign that he’s on the right trail. He suddenly smells something… unexpected. The thickets begin to rustle, the air begins to hum, and unkind things emerge.

Save Sméagol, then try to hide.
<color=red>Sméagol must survive</color>

The sound of horns and ironshod feet clangor in the evening air. In the distance, you see torchlights flicker into life on the walls of what looks to be an old tower. Cursing your own carelessness, you dash into the thickets, Orc horns blaring close behind. A fallen tree lying against mossy boulders must serve as a hiding place.

You glimpse torchlit shapes of many enemies moving through the trees. By luck or fate, none come closer than a hundred feet of you. After some time, the horns stop braying and scattered groups of Orcs return sullenly through the forest.

Just as you begin to feel the danger has passed, you hear nearby rustling and the sound of voices. You recognize the grating speech of the enemy and… another voice. A whining, pitiful one you’d hoped never to hear again. Sméagol must have followed you, and has been captured by Orcs.

Loathsome as the creature may be, something tells you not to stand idly by while Sméagol is dragged towards certain death.

Defeat the Marsh Adder.
<color=red>Sméagol must survive</color>

For hours you wade along precarious and narrow strips of land, soft ground sucking at your boots while Sméagol encourages you onwards. You glimpse a tall shape above the fog some distance ahead. Could this be Sméagol’s “hill of haunted stones”? “No, no, precious! Not cold hill, not black stones, not Sméagol’s!” he croaks, bobbing his head at your foolishness. “Haunted hill further south. Sméagol not go there, gollum, gollum!” He sniffs around the edges of a nearby pool, adding, “Old tower of tall men, that is, rotten and broken. Orcses and wagons and Baggins rest there tonight.” Without warning, he darts headfirst into the pool with a splash, emerging with a wriggling carp between his teeth. He slithers back to dry land and begins to eat it with glee. Suddenly, the water explodes and a giant serpent rises from the pool, its forked tongue undulating in anticipation. A half-eaten fish is thrown aside in panic.

Pickpocket the key, or defeat enemies to take it by force.
<color=red>Sméagol must survive</color>

As darkness thickens, orange light from Orc fires bathe the dilapidated walls of the ruined tower. Your spirits sink as you witness the last prisoners, no longer wrapped in cocoons, marched into the stronghold. Orcs and Goblins seem to be everywhere.

How will you get to Bilbo? And if you do, how will you get away?

You decide to chance entering the tower through a small door in the tower’s eastern side. As you quietly approach, the door snaps open and a group of armed Orcs emerge. The last of them brandishes a large key, with which it proceeds to lock the door. As the door locks with a dull clunk, the Orcs make to start their patrol.
Final Encounter: With Sméagol's help, try to find out where Bilbo was taken. Sméagol must survive

After sneaking through the tower door, you emerge into a huge chamber full of reeking supplies, fallen stones, and intruding vegetation. A number of large chains emerge from openings in the floor along the walls. The chains terminate into an iron box bolted to the far side of the chamber. The box bristles with rusty hooks and mechanical wheels.

You glide quietly through the room, keen to avoid attention. You peek into the connecting rooms, hoping for clues as to where the Orcs are storing their prisoners.

Steps are suddenly heard on the flagstones coming in your direction. After a few moments, a smallish Orc enters the chamber to rummage through supplies. The light of its torch happens to catch one of your buckles, causing the Orc to glance lazily in your direction. For a second, it seems to not have understood what its seeing, but then recognition flares in its ugly face.

You’ve fought your way into the forest of Mirkwood to rescue the famous Bilbo Baggins.

After fighting spiders and bears, and meeting a strange creature by the name of Sméagol, you arrive at a ruined structure deep in the forest. The old ruin operates as a staging point for mysterious slave caravans managed by a host of Orcs. You believe the old Hobbit is imprisoned in the tower.

You manage to sneak into the structure, but without warning you are betrayed by Sméagol. Triggering an ancient mechanical trap, the contemptible creature drops you into a rancid basement.

Knocked unconscious by falling debris, you’ve finally come to your senses.

Ufthak’s room is as dark as his mood.

He tears into the cold meat, juices gushing down his scarred jaw. Things are afoot the great Orc cannot explain: Attacks in the forest, a ravaged patrol, the storage room mysteriously emptied… Ufthak grunts and angrily throws his empty drinking horn against the wall, where it splinters to join a pile of dry bones and other detritus on the floor.

Breathing heavily from climbing the stairs, Ufthak’s mewling steward, Slagid, worms his thin frame into the room. Must the Goblin always be clutching one of his parchments?

“What do you want, worm?” Ufthak licks dry the bone and it joins the drinking horn.

“A visitor has come, Ufthak,” Slagid lisps and adjusts his cloak nervously. “From Dol Guldur.”

Fear is not a common emotion in Orcs, and Ufthak considers himself uncommonly brave. Even so, he cannot halt the tendrils of dread that shoots down his spine.

“The Mouth of the Cold Ones has come.”

You force your bruised body to stand, head throbbing like a Dwarven feast. Your garments are soaked and dripping from lying in stagnant water. Now, where has that blighted Sméagol dumped you?

The ceiling above must have retreated to its former position. Through a crack in the wall, moonlight paints the dank cellar in a bloom of gray light. Your feet splash as they move, for the nearby swamp has laced its way into the tower’s foundations. Stale water and light-starved cattails fill most of the cellar. White tadpoles skitter about in the water, and thin lizards bob their heads on the slimy walls. The far end of the cellar is hidden in shadow.

Did the shadow just move? It rolls and ripples before emerging into the moonlight. It’s not a shadow at all, but some vast slug. It extends its behemoth head and eye-tentacles towards you, snorts a drizzle of fetid saliva, and proceeds to tug its enormous body under itself. It seems to have made up its mind.

You are food.
Survive for 4 rounds as you fight your way across the hall to the far door

A tall figure awaits Ufthak in the tower’s main hall. He wears cold-hammered black armor, and a black cowl shadows his features except for the unnatural glint in his gray eyes.

Ufthak purposefully strides into the hall to stand before the imposing figure. Damned if he’ll show the fear he feels. The Mouth of Dol Guldur is not fooled and smiles cruelly.

“You have message from Cold Ones?” Ufthak snarls, discomfited by the unnatural chill emanating from Dol Guldur’s favored messenger.

“I’ve ridden without halt, so I shall be precise.” The voice is like frozen stone. “I’m to inform you that the masters need the promised slaves with haste. The last batch… expired faster than anticipated.”

“New prisoners all here, Mouth,” Ufthak grunts. “My warriors provision first, leave for Black Hill next dark.”

At that moment, the tower rumbles and jolts as if a great fist had struck its foundations.

The enormous slug falls and the walls tremble, sousing the air with an avalanche of grime.

Behind a patch of bogland ivy, you discover a narrow staircase and commence to climb the moldy steps at once. While ascending, a clamor can be heard in the tower above. Harsh yells, clanging of doors, and the bellows of a great Orc. How will you ever get out?

The stairs emerge into a derelict alcove, overgrown with cobwebs and moss. It faces a great room, finely decorated of old, but now ruined and forgotten. As the racket of the enemy grows closer, you’ve no doubt that he’ll soon be upon you.

Speed may be your only hope. You rush towards a set of oaken doors on the far wall when disaster strikes: as you emerge from the alcove, a troop of Orcs slog into the room. They roar in excitement and draw their weapons as more enemies arrive.

You are surrounded!
Final Encounter: Drive off Sméagol and save Bilbo

You’ve broken through the enemy ranks and reached the heavy oaken door. Rushing into the room beyond, you hastily barricade the door behind you. Hinges rattle and splinters fly as the Orcs administer powerful blows, urged on by a deep booming voice. The door won’t hold long. A hiss causes you to turn as you realize that you’ve stumbled into the towers’ gaol. Sméagol is crouching before one of the cells, glaring at you with undisguised loathing. You don’t have to guess whose cell this is. Sméagol hisses again, rising protectively before the cell door. “Stops them we must, gollum. Nasty masters cannot have Precious!” The door booms again and several planks fly across the room. Sméagol shrieks as he charges you, face twisted with deranged fury.

Board the raft to try and escape the pursuing forces. 
<color=red>Bilbo must survive</color>

To rescue Bilbo Baggins from Mirkwood spiders, you’ve fought bears, a monstrous slug, met the treacherous Sméagol, and much more. You’ve discovered that the great spiders are in league with a host of Orcs, collecting slaves for some devilry to the south.

You managed to free Bilbo from the Orcs and their captain, Ufthak.

Escaping on a fast-flowing stream, the current has taken you several miles away before you're able to swim onto dry land. Looking to the northeast, the sight of distant torches confirms what you fear: that Ufthak and his minions are in pursuit.

Bilbo shakes with cold. You must find some way to reach the River Anduin and get the old Hobbit to safety. After following the bank for some miles, you catch the sound of pounding ahead. You soon come upon a terrible sight. A Hill Troll has beaten two Beorning fishermen to death and now looks to be deciding which to eat first.

Lapping against the shore is what you’re looking for: a large fishing raft.
Resolve all Hazards to continue downriver. Bilbo must survive

You struggle to manage the unfamiliar vessel as it lurches and wobbles on the narrow stream. After some hours, the tributary widens at last to connect with the mighty river Anduin. You carefully guide the raft through the eddies that roil in the junction of the two currents, and soon find yourself rapidly floating south on the great river.

Suddenly, an Orc arrow lodges itself in your raft with a thud. Cruel shapes move on the forested eastern shore, easily keeping up with your clumsy raft.

Cursing the persistence of Orcs, you reluctantly steer towards the more turbulent western side of the river, hoping to put more distance between the raft and the enemy archers. Alas, recent rainfalls in the Misty Mountains has given the river fuel, and the rapids soon become treacherous. Very treacherous.

Deny the crossing to hold the enemy at bay until you can escape upon the water.
<color=red>Bilbo must survive</color>

Barely surviving the turgid rapids, you’re overjoyed to see the wider Anduin ahead. You fervently hope the Orcs have given up pursuit and returned to their decrepit tower. You’ll keep to the river until you reach the banks of Lórien. The Elves will surely shelter you, and allow Bilbo to recover from his ordeal.

Lost in thoughts of the Golden Wood, you fail to notice the change in the river until it is too late.

Without warning, the raft bucks with a wooden screech, and halts. The jolt throws you forward, and several bags are thrown into the river. At first you’re confused by the impact, but realize the widening of the river has shallowed the water. Enough, in fact, that you are able to wade into the water to retrieve your packs.

When a roar suddenly erupts from the eastern bank, your enemy’s plan is laid bare. The Orcs knew about this ford, and have waited for this moment.

The howls intensify as the Orcs and Goblins emerge from the treeline and rush into the shallow waters.
Final Encounter: Protect Bilbo until wardens of Lórien arrive; then defeat every Enemy in play. Bilbo must survive

The golden haze of Lórien is finally in sight. Weary beyond words, your mood is somber.

You settle the spent raft on a bank of soft grasses and marigolds. Ahead, the edge of the Golden Wood is blurred by a light haze—as if looking into a dream. Beautiful and perilous is that place. A sanctuary for those who come with peace in their hearts, an ossuary for those that come with violence.

The end of your journey in sight, the oh-so-familiar thunder of heavy boots nearly breaks your resolve.

Furious that you escaped his trap at the ford, Ufthak has crossed west of the Anduin with a strong force and has sped for days to intercept you. They emerge from the nearby pinewood like a rotten stain on the green field. Your tired frames are no match for their strong legs, and Ufthak’s host easily moves between you the golden trees.

In baleful cacophony, the Orcs howl as they attack. Yet, did you hear something else above the din? The call of the clear horns, and of horns answering?
WHICH 	way to go you say

Having rescued your friend and left the spiders’ lair, you must decide upon your next course of action. Though you have no idea how many Orcs patrol these woods, their presence threatens the success of your mission. Do you stay off the main path and find an alternate route around them, or confront them directly in hopes of pushing on quickly?
Resolve Cocoon to rescue your captured Hero and allow travel from this Location

Orcs encroaching so far into Mirkwood? The King of Dale's concern was clearly justified, and your mission has taken on new urgency. You head down an overgrown trail to escape any other Orcs who might pursue. Senses alert to danger, you react swiftly when a new threat appears! Giant spiders drop from the trees to attack your party. You drive them back, only to discover that this was only a diversion—more spiders lunge from the snarled underbrush behind you! With horrifying speed, they wrap one of your friends in a silken cocoon and drag the captive off to be devoured. You cannot abandon your companion to such a fate.

Free your friend from the Cocoon

Placeholder Following the Spiders has lead you towards the Enchanted Stream. Carefully crossing the foul river on a fallen log, you do not look upwards until it is too late! A member of your party is grabbed by the spiders before you can react.
Resolve Find Your Friends to allow travel from this Location

Your mission for the King of Dale has uncovered the presence of Orcs in Mirkwood Forest. Troubling news indeed. You make camp after a long day traveling ever further in this foul place. Sleep comes quickly to your tired eyes, but unsettling dreams disturb your rest—nightmares filled with bulbous eyes gleaming from the shadows and skittering legs echoing in the dark. Awakening in the wan pre-dawn light, you find it wasn't a dream at all. While you slept, the giant spiders of Mirkwood carried off your friends—and have returned to claim you as well! You must escape these vile creatures and seek out your companions at once!

You must escape these vile creatures and seek out your companions at once!
Resolve either Along the Stream or Investigate the Village to travel immediately to the next Location

You have rescued your friends and escaped the spiders' lair, only to find yourself lost in the vastness of Mirkwood. Far from the relative safety of the Forest Road, the woods are a dark tangle of twisted trees. It is impossible to know the correct direction to travel within this wooded maze. If you are to find your way out and continue your mission for the King of Dale, you must first find some landmarks to get your bearings…
Final Encounter: Defeat Giant Marsh Worm to complete the Quest

At long last, the stream you have been following empties into a wide bog. The Anduin River vale must lie beyond this morass. Though the moist ground sucks greedily at your feet with each step, you make your way across the swamp doggedly and with no small amount of relief at leaving the accursed wood behind. Just then, the bog ahead erupts in a shower of brackish water! A Giant Marsh Worm lunges for you hungrily with a speed that belies its size…
Final Encounter: Defeat all Enemies in play to complete the Quest

Navigating through the dense forest toward the smoke is no easy task, but at last you find the remains of an old Woodsmen village. Even more welcome to your eyes is the clear blue sky in the distance: you stand near the eaves of Mirkwood! Your relief is short-lived, however, as the village is overrun with Orcs! They spot your weary group, making it clear that you must fight to reach the Anduin Vale.
Defeat each Troll or resolve Delay Until Dawn to complete the Quest

Freed from the chains, Grimbeorn claps you on the shoulder in thanks. You start toward the river, but he surprises you by heading deeper into the woods. "More Trolls lurk nearby," he growls. "We shall teach them the folly of crossing Grimbeorn the Old!" You dash after the Skin-changer, his shouts as easy to follow as his trail through the brush. Bursting into a moonlit clearing, you see Grimbeorn facing three massive Trolls. “A barrel of beer to any who bring me a Troll’s head!” he proclaims, lunging at the nearest foe. You will need to defeat the Trolls outright or find a way to keep them occupied until the sun rises!

Resolve Hidden Path to allow travel from this Location

Shadows loom in Mirkwood Forest, threatening the lands that surround it. The King of Dale decides that the peoples living along the dark forest’s borders must unite against this menace. You agree to act as his envoy to the Beornings, reclusive Skin-changers who dwell in the Anduin Vale to the west under the rule of their chieftain, Grimbeorn the Old. This is a journey fraught with peril, since you must travel through Mirkwood itself. The Elf-path that crosses the forest’s northern reaches offers the safest route—but, while searching for this hidden path, you find yourself surrounded by servants of the growing darkness…

Defeat Ungoliant's Spawn to complete the Quest

You hack through the spiders’ webs but advance only a short distance when a massive form emerges from the gloom. The largest spider you have ever seen blocks your way forward, while her many offspring gather behind you to cut off any retreat. There is no turning back. You must defeat Ungoliant's Spawn.

Your friend wasn't there! But you do hear the sounds of battle not far off, moving quickly, you find your friend fighting off the massive spider from earlier.
Resolve Continue Downstream or Search for a Path to advance immediately to the next Location

A stream winds its way through the twisted roots of ancient trees that crowd the riverbank. You follow the water's course as best you can, battling uneven terrain each step of the way. Though the stream should lead you from Mirkwood eventually, you wonder if a less arduous option can be found.

Resolve River Bend to allow travel from this Location

You steer the raft away from the rapids along the opposite shore far from your pursuers. Here the waters are calmer than before but the current remains swift and threatens to dash your flimsy craft upon rocks strewn along your course. You resolve to navigate your way to safety…

You steer the raft away from the rapids along the opposite shore far from your pursuers. Here the waters are calmer than before but the current remains swift and threatens to dash your flimsy craft upon rocks strewn along your course. You resolve to navigate your way to safety…
Avoid the Patrols or Defeat all Enemies

Approaching the Tower, the creature guides you through a hidden path along the base of the hill. There are a few small groups of Orcs here, but if you are quiet and strike quickly, you may be able to advance without raising the alarm…

The little creature, who seems to call himself Gollum leads you into the forest. You spy the trail of the Goblins leading off to the south. Gollum seems to think following it is a bad idea and knows a better route. "Yes, much better... quieter... less goblins. Yes. Gollum." Now to decide if you trust your new friend or not. A few stragglers from the group harry you as you make up your mind.
Resolve either Follow the Stream or Climb the Hill to advance immediately to the next Location

Searching, you find one of your friends struggling in their webs. They have a group of spiders around them...

Your patience has paid off. You see a tower in the distance that Gollum says is where they took the hobbit. The forest isn't done with you just yet though, a marshy section lays between you and the tower.

Your patience has paid off. You see a tower in the distance that Gollum says is where they took the hobbit. The forest isn't done with you just yet though, a marshy section lays between you and the tower.
Final Encounter: Defeat Giant Marsh Worm to complete the Quest

The stream you have been following empties into a wide bog. The Anduin River vale must lie beyond this morass. Though the moist ground sucks greedily at your feet with each step, you make your way across the swamp doggedly and with no small amount of relief at leaving the accursed wood behind. Just then, the bog ahead erupts in a shower of brackish water! A Giant Marsh Worm lunges for you hungrily with a speed that belies its size…
Resolve Escape the Forest to complete the Quest

After a long, desperate search you find the trail at last. Overgrown and covered in animal tracks, this nonetheless promises to be your best means of reaching the Anduin Vale. You make good time at first, but soon realize that your presence has not gone unnoticed. While the path may ease travel, the roused denizens of Mirkwood shall make you fight for every step…

Resolve Follow Grimbeorn's Trail to allow travel from this Location

Traversing the Anduin River has brought you from the Forest Gate south to the Beornings. You explain that yours is a mission of great urgency: you must speak with Grimbeorn the Old about what you have uncovered in Mirkwood, and share the offer of alliance from the King of Dale. The tribe of Skin-changers regrets that their chieftain is not present. He was last seen as a great bear, roaming south toward his stony outlook at the Carrock. You cannot afford to wait for his return. In order to find Grimbeorn, you will have to go after him at once…

You decide that the mission is too important to confront an unknown number of Orcs. You seek to bypass them by taking an alternate path, but the trail soon becomes increasingly overgrown and the forest floor covered in thick shrouds of webbing. You hear the skittering sound of many legs encroaching all around as it becomes clear you’ve stumbled into another spiders’ nest! You must fight past the chitinous horde if you wish to press on through Mirkwood this day.

Though you have broken through the spiders' lair, the confusion of battle has left you far from any trail. Searching tirelessly, you at last spot a path on the far side of a dark, unnatural-looking stream. As you look for a place to ford in this bleak place, an enormous creature emerges from the water to attack!

Defeat all Enemies in play to complete the Quest

Having fought past the Orc patrol, you move with haste down the Elf-path. The forest becomes increasingly bleak as you advance. Rotting leaves squelch beneath your feet and a fetid stench fills the air. Soon you discover the source of the foulness: a dark, unnatural-looking stream cuts across the path. You are looking for a means to cross when you hear the unmistakable guttural whoops and snarls of yet more Orcs. A harsh shout splits the air as the Orcs lunge at you in a frenzied assault!

Placeholder Arriving at the location of Bilbo's capture, you find a group of spiders, but no Hobbit. You must find out what happened to Gloin's friend. Following the spiders may lead you back to their lair...

You've managed to free one of your companions, but the second remains missing! You find another group of cocoons, but this time, instead of just spiders, the cocoons are being moved by Goblins! You must hurry!
Resolve Rescue Your Friends to allow travel from this Location

Searching through the night, you find your friends at last. They are held within a dark glade, bound in cocoons made of strong webbed cords. You slip through the shadows, seemingly unnoticed by the spiders in their webs high above. However, as you raise your blade to cut your companions free, the creatures drop to the forest floor and attack!

Resolve Escape the Spiders' Lair to allow travel from this Location

You've managed to cut your companions loose, but the spiders are determined to recapture you. They spin giant webs from tree to tree, trapping you in their lair. You will have to sunder the thick strands in order to escape.

Bilbo wasn't there, but the lair is just ahead. However, your actions haven't gone unnoticed as three massive spiders drop from the forest canopy towards you...
Resolve Rescue Grimbeorn to advance immediately from this Location

You track Grimbeorn throughout the day, and shortly after sunset, you find evidence of a violent struggle. It is clear that the mighty Skin-changer faced a powerful foe… or foes. You see no further sign of Grimbeorn's tracks, either as man or bear. Instead, you discern the large, telltale footprints of Trolls. Fearing the worst, you follow the tracks to an impromptu camp set up under a rocky overhang. Grimbeorn lies in chains at the feet of some Trolls who cackle about the great feast they plan to make of him! You need hear no more—drawing your weapons, you rush to his rescue.

You stand at the shore of the Great River. To the south lies your destination: the land of the Beornings. Though the trials of Mirkwood Forest lay behind you pursuing Orcs remain a threat. You make haste along the riverbank looking for some means of shaking the Orcs off your trail. At last you spot a raft which should speed your journey. As you approach the craft a shadow falls before you: a fearsome Hill Troll looms up from behind a cluster of rocks! He lunges toward you his eyes gleaming with murderous intent…

You decide that the mission is too important to allow for delays. Returning to the Elf-path, you plan to confront the Orcs directly. You had heard no reports of Orc patrols before your recent encounter, after all, so you gamble that their numbers are not insurmountable.

You decide that the mission is too important to allow for delays. Returning to the Elf-path, you plan to confront the Orcs directly. You had heard no reports of Orc patrols before your recent encounter, after all, so you gamble that their numbers are not insurmountable.
Defeat the next two Enemies that appear

Bilbo waved at the Beorning guards as he passed into the twilight landscape beyond the gate. A sickle moon was rising and calm winds moved the grasses. 

Glóin was to have greeted them at Beorn’s Hall, but the old Dwarf had not yet arrived. He’d wished to accompany them on their journey through Mirkwood to Erebor. 

Despite weary feet and a full stomach, Bilbo was in need of an evening stroll to sing and to think, and hoped to be the first to greet Glóin on the road.

Óin, Nori, and Bombur were happy to sip the famous mead of the House of Beorn. Especially Bombur.

In the quiet way of Hobbits, Bilbo moved invisibly through the night. Memories and thoughts of distant friends lay heavy on his heart that evening. The secret longing, the deep dull ache that never would entirely abate, had grown stronger in recent days.

Lost in memory, Bilbo wandered through meadow and plain until he found himself at the edge of the Greenwood in the last rays of the sinking sun. Scents of growth and decay drifted from the trees. A symphony of evening birds and insects was on the air.

Bilbo came out of his reverie as something stirred in the tall bushes nearby. Glóin, perhaps? 

What emerged was not Glóin.
Secure the camp from the spider incursion!

For days, a strange pull had drawn the creature towards the forest’s edge.

Desire drove it on. The creature missed the cool air and precious darkness under stone, yet for years it had roamed the Wilderland, faithfully searching. Hunting. Craving.

A nearby noise attracted its attention, and the creature slid through the branches to investigate. 

As it peered out of the trees onto a small trail, its ancient heart began to beat rapidly. For there it stood… the thief, the forever cursed. Finally.

“Baggins.”
Destroy the spiders' nest to complete the Quest

The creature hesitated.

It would have struck without mercy, had not that filthy Dwarf been with Baggins. The creature feared the strength of Dwarves. Fortunately, it knew of a safer way to snare its prey.

For the creature had made friends in the forest over the years. It had learned their chittering tongue, and they’d helped each other in dark deeds.

Noiselessly under shadowed boughs, the creature slid off to plead with the lady of the nearby brood. Tasty flesh it would offer her. For himself, the creature desired only a tiny thing. A trinket.

The smallest of things.

Quite simply, this means that The Lord of the Rings™: Living Card Game™ is still in active development. This means that features, cards, effects, and mechanics are subject to change for any number of reasons based on data acquired from actual play and user feedback. It also means that you will run into bugs or quirks from time to time that our team is working actively to fix. During Early Access, we have roughed in a Tutorial that teaches you the game, but that requires much additional polish. If you do run into any play issues or bugs, or have any feedback, please let us know at our Steam Discussions page. We appreciate your taking part in our Early Access development, which will help us to refine, balance, and improve the game on our path to full release. We'll work to make Sauron more clever, the animations more plentiful and snappier, and the game more challenging and exciting. With your participation, we wish to make this a fantastic experience that you can enjoy for many years to come. Now… on to Middle-earth and the adventures that await you there!

The first Campaign in The Lord of the Rings: Living Card Game.
Acting as envoy for the King of Dale, you must venture through Mirkwood and down the Anduin to the land of the Beornings, to seek an audience with Grimbeorn the Old.
The famous Bilbo Baggins has been captured in Mirkwood! Vowing to rescue him before he suffers a terrible fate, you soon suspect that there's more to his abduction than meets the eye…
The One Ring Classic "This is the One Ring that he lost many ages ago, to the great weakening of his power. He greatly desires it—but he must not get it." —Gandalf, The Fellowship of the Ring

Mount Doom Still far away, forty miles at least, they saw Mount Doom, its feet founded in ashen ruin, its huge cone rising to a great height, where its reeking head was swathed in cloud. —The Return of the King
Istari "…it is said: Do not meddle in the affairs of Wizards, for they are subtle and quick to anger." —Gildor, The Fellowship of the Ring
Mirkwood "Well, here is Mirkwood!" said Gandalf. "The greatest of the forests of the Northern world. I hope you like the look of it." —The Hobbit

Shire Forty leagues it stretched from the Far Downs to the Brandywine Bridge, and fifty from the northern moors to the marshes in the south. The Hobbits named it the Shire… —The Fellowship of the Ring
Steward of Gondor "…this City and realm has rested in the charge of the Stewards for many long years…" —Aragorn, The Return of the King
The One Ring One Ring to rule them all, One Ring to find them, One Ring to bring them all and in the darkness bind them… —The Fellowship of the Ring

Though he comes from humble beginnings, Samwise Gamgee rises to any challenge with unmatched bravery and determination. This pack is tailor-made for cleverness, helping you sneak past the watchful Eye of Sauron to claim victory through daring and stealth.

Faramir does not seek glory in danger without purpose. Touched by the wisdom and sadness of the Elder Race, he is shrewd in battle. This pack gives you the abilities needed to outlast Sauron’s forces and stand victorious at the battle’s end.

Éowyn is renowned for her courage and compassion. With inner strength strong as tempered steel, she stands unflinching before even the greatest threats. This pack emphasizes cards that help your party defend against any threat no matter how numerous or mighty.

Legolas has unmatched prowess as an archer. Employing acute senses and breathtaking agility, he outmaneuvers foes to defeat them before they even see him coming. This pack taps into Elvish tactics, using wits and swiftness to strike down enemies with deadly accuracy.

Dwalin of the House of Durin leads the battle against all enemies of the Dwarves—whether Orcs, Wargs, Spiders, or any other foe. This pack focuses on enhancing Characters’ abilities to overwhelm Enemy ranks and resolve Objectives.

At first the globe was dark, black as jet, with the moonlight gleaming on its surface. Then there came a faint glow and stir in the heart of it, and it held his eyes… —The Two Towers

The Palantír is a bonus system. This wondrous object of mysterious ability grants rewards when you gaze into it. You spend a Palantír View each time you gaze into the Palantír. You then receive two rewards from the following possibilities: Valor Points; cards you do not own already; or new cosmetic items. Palantír Views are precious things. You can gain them through exceptional gameplay or through special boons bestowed upon you.
